data.text: Does Pee Scent Attract Bears?

Here’s a question for campers. When stealth camping in the middle of nowhere, I understand you hang food and toiletries so not to attract bears near your site. But to an extreme is using things like deodorant, bug spray, soap or shampoo from earlier in the day any cause for concern. And if you’re having to go pee in the night, will that scent attract also? Been wondering this for some time now. My take is that bears can smell anything from quite a distance. Thanks for any input.
Following
data.author: Johnny Cameron

data.text: You are probably much more likely to have problems from racoons and small wildlings than a big ole bear. More especially if you're in established campsites were those animals have discovered a steady buffet of goodies! They will also chew sweat salt impregnated equipment like pack straps or saddle clinches.
data.author: Randle Gay

data.text: depends on where you are. A determined bear can get into anything no matter how well you hang it. Small rodents will chew up straps, gear and tents. Best to have a needle and thread for such times.
data.author: Tom Heutte

data.text: I completely agree, Tom. Needle and thread...or the old standby - duct tape!
data.author: Randle Gay

data.text: I hear the clear gorilla tape works wonders also!
data.author: David Kendall

data.text: Good to know! Sounds like I should hang the sweat drenched bike also!! ; )
data.author: David Kendall

data.text:
As a regular stealth camper/backpacker/bikepacker, the only time you really have to worry about attracting bears is if you are in grizzly country in alaska/canada/montana/wyoming/idaho. But you should know how to leave no trace--dealing with your waste, packing out what you packed in, limiting your impact on the land to only footprints (and maybe not even that). We are way more impactful to the world than it is to us. If you want to know more, check this out. https://lnt.org/why/7-principles/
The 7 Principles - Leave No Trace Center for Outdoor Ethics
lnt.org
data.author: Kattina Rabdau

data.text: Not true!! Attracting black bear here in the White Mountain National Forest is a real danger. The Leve No Trace reference, while a necessary education WILL NOT prevent marauding bears from ruining your camping trip by either eating all your food or being startled by us and harming us. It's rare, but it happens, especially with a momma bear with young cubs.
data.author: Mike Parton

data.text: The only bears I have to fear are "gummi bears." High glycemic index! ;-)
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.author: Peter van Huffel

data.text: it's me, just taking a nap
data.author: Peter van Huffel

data.text:
A kid in NY woke up with a brown bear choking his leg because he had spilled some food on himself. Not sure where you live but: https://www.google.com/amp/s/people.com/human-interest/12-year-old-bitten-by-black-bear-during-boy-scout-camping-new-york/%3Famp%3Dtrue
12-Year-Old Bitten by Black Bear During Boy Scout Camping Trip in New York
people.com
data.author: Anita Valencia Bozzo

data.text: I personally made the decision not to bring deodorant with me since I was told repeatedly that it’s unnecessary weight as you sweat it off very quickly. Embrace the stink! But in all seriousness bears were a serious worry for me in the Rockies, so I kept my food in a bear bag and my bike away from my tent since it stored my food all day. I decided in the moment each night if I thought it was necessary to tie the bear bag up or just leave it in my pack. I also had sleep designated clothes that I changed I to and left my cycling clothes in my panniers. You’re also meant to go to the bathroom 200ft away from your campsite. I didn’t do the level of stealth camping you’re speaking of, partially due to bear concerns so there were usually facilities nearby I could use.
data.author: Meghan Bridget

data.text: thanks for the reply! I’m travelling across Canada and also have these concerns. I would far prefer to just stay in motels and hostels through the Rockies tbh. Maybe it’s possible. Thanks again.
data.author: David Kendall

data.text: at the end of the day I’d put my life above my bike or panniers, so the main thing is to keep those far enough away from the tent at night, and be conscious not just of your own behaviors but of those camping near you if you are in campsites.
data.author: Meghan Bridget

data.text: anything with scent do not use in forest. simple.
data.author: Kevin Hillier

data.text: And your own body odor?
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: it seems if you stink the bugs do not bother you. well after a while in forest you just have a natural smell that soaps an stuff do not stay on you. just swim once a day your good.
data.author: Kevin Hillier

data.text: I think bears would smell a person just as much as they would smell food in bags or whatever. So why isn't the advice to hang yourself along with the food from some tree branch?
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Definitely keep a whistle and bear spray with you.
data.author: Keli Lynn Kennedy

data.text: Bears climb trees better than you think. Hanging it is pointless. Don't eat in the tent. Ever. Seal food tightly.
data.author: Doug Keyport

data.text: #1, Do Not eat sitting in your Tent.
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Remember, black bear encounters usually last a few seconds and almost always include the bear running away from humans. Food should be hung away from your camp, If you’re worried about the toiletries then don’t bring them. If you’re backcountry enough to be alone with bears then you likely don’t need a wash. I’ve been on the road for 12 days at the moment, 2 showers, zero deodorant. Always carry bear spray in grizzly country, you are no match for the that animal. A black bear, not so much.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: Here is the deal with soaps, deodorant, shampoos, they all attract bugs, not bears. I am way more concerned about stinging and biting bugs than I am about bears… I have been face to face with bares many times and have never been bitten… can’t how many times I’ve been lunch to a bug and ruined the rest of my trip.
data.author: Mike Rose

data.text: can you provide us references for the assertion "...soaps, deodorant, shampoos, they all attract bugs, not bears."? Would love to hear this from multiple, scientific sources as a "fact" check. TIA!
data.author: Mike Parton

data.text: Come to Australia. We only have drop bears here.
data.author: Lu Cornwell

data.text: Our bear in a suburban Kelowna campground loved our camp dish soap. I did go and apologize to the ranger. She was concerned that these bears wind up being dealt with.
data.author: Shelley Williams

data.text: In Sequoia NP one time, a guy was trapped in his tent by a bear, he was eating in the porch. The ranger chased it away. That evening one of my companions had food poisoning, and was terrified the bear would come back, attracted by the smell of puke. In the morning the dude next door had had the wing mirror of his VW combi ripped off. He'd left his food in a cooler inside the van. A week later we were up Whitney and ground squirrels and groundhogs managed to get into our stash of food. Despite it hanging! Same trip we met a couple if guys who had been deep in the backcountry, surviving on fish they had caught, as despite hanging their food in a tree, they lost it all to a bear. They were three days from a road head.
data.author: Eddie Energie
